children.subject: Thank you for the advice! The thing is, I don't know what would be more worthwhile for me (at the moment), internships/recruiting, or maximizing my GPA. Both are very important aspects for student development. The personal project sounds and seems the most interesting to me, but I don't want to regret not putting in that extra effort into 61C.
Go for the personal project then. Most people take 61C without prior study and do fine.

Hi, upcoming fourth-year here. 

Depends on what your goals are. For internships/recruiting, I think a great way to gain practical programming experience would be to try to do a personal project, as you said. Maybe do a few online tutorials first on the type of project you want to build (web dev probably has the lowest barrier to entry?), and then just dive in and try to own whatever you're building from start to finish. You'll probably learn a lot from the process - things like how software components come together, common programming/design patterns, lots of debugging, basic shell commands, and how to google & ask the right questions on stack overflow. It'll also give you stuff to talk about in an interview.

With that being said, if your goal is to do well in school and maximize your GPA, it may be worth to preview 61C. I personally loved the class and thought the projects were fun, so maybe you can try to look at some of those ahead of time.

Second the poster above. I'm doing an internship and taking a summer course (and many other people have similar or greater workloads) and still trying to get a jump start for the fall. Obviously, don't stress yourself out for something that you're choosing to do, but I wouldn't say you can't do both. You don't necessarily need to prepare for 61C ahead of time (or study the entire thing) and personal projects are something you can invest as much time into as you see fit. I think experience will be just as important in the future for you as your GPA, so a personal project is a great choice, but you can try to invest maybe a couple hours a week into 61C (based on how your life goes) to just get yourself accustomed to the material/work. Or just do the personal project, you might not need to study for 61C ahead of time depending on your schedule next sem.

history.content: Hello, I am having a hard time deciding on what the best use of my summer time would be. I have two main goals: prepare for the upcoming semester so I can do well in my courses (particularly CS61C) and practicing (mainly improving) my programming skills (to be competent for recruiting/internships) by starting a side-project, for which I currently have none to call my own, among other things like reviewing 61B material (if there are also some other ways to gain practical programming experience, please let me know!). I already have a full time job for the summer (nothing major related, mainly for financial reasons), which has made me realize that I will inevitably have to focus on one goal more than the other due to my limited time. I am an incoming sophomore. Advice from anyone who has been in this dilemma would be helpful, thank you!
history.subject: Summer Priorities
